title: MathClean: A Benchmark for Synthetic Mathematical Data Cleaning
author: Hao Liang (Peking University), Zefeng He (Nanjing University), Meiyi Qiang (Beijing Institute of Technology), Yongzhen Guo (Ant Group), Wentao Zhang (Peking University), Bin Cui (Peking University)
relevance_why: The evaluation of synthetic mathematical data quality and error detection can inform the development of more robust algorithms for audio and speech processing, particularly in generating data-driven models.
background: Creating a benchmark for cleaning synthetic mathematical questions and answers through rigorous evaluation and error-type classification.
contribution: MathClean introduces a dataset of 4,000 mathematical problems to systematically assess data correctness, achieving enhanced methods for error detection and classification.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing benchmarks focus primarily on traditional mathematical reasoning without detailed error analysis.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work emphasizes error-type classification alongside correctness detection, providing diverse error types and human-annotated examples.

key_innovation: Develops a benchmark that not only assesses correctness but also categorizes errors, thus offering deeper insights into the weaknesses of current models.
real_world_impact: The findings can lead to improved algorithms for synthetic data generation in various domains, enhancing machine learning models' effectiveness in reasoning tasks.
limitations: The performance of state-of-the-art models on this benchmark remains suboptimal, indicating room for further improvement.

new_terms.synthetic mathematical data: **Synthetic mathematical data** refers to artificially created mathematical problems and solutions aimed at training machine learning models.
new_terms.error-type classification: **Error-type classification** is the process of categorizing the kinds of errors present in a dataset, such as logic errors or computational errors.

open_sourcing: Code and data are available at https://github.com/YuYingLi0/MathClean.
